column1: Alice becomes bored with her history lesson on the Norman conquest of England and expresses her want of adventure
column2: leading her to a riverbank. There
column3: Alice spots a passing White Rabbit in a waistcoat
column4: exclaiming that he is """late" for a very important "date""." She gives chase
column5: following him into a large rabbit hole. She sees him leave through a tiny door
column6: whose talking knob advises her to shrink to an appropriate height by drinking from a bottle marked """Drink" "Me""." She does so and floats out through the keyhole into a sea of her own tears
column7: which she had cried after eating a biscuit marked """Eat" "Me""
column8: which caused her to grow very large. As she continues to follow the Rabbit, she meets numerous characters, including Tweedledum and Tweedledee, who recount the tale of "The" Walrus and the "Carpenter""." Alice tracks the Rabbit to his house; he mistakes her for his housemaid and sends her to retrieve his gloves. While searching
column9: she finds and eats another cookie marked """Eat" "Me""" and grows large again
column10: getting stuck in the house. Thinking her a monster
column11: he brings the Dodo to help expel her. When the Dodo decides to burn the house down
column12: Alice escapes by eating a carrot from the Rabbit's garden
column13: which causes her to shrink to three inches tall
column14: and continues following him. Along the way
column15: she meets a garden of talking flowers who initially welcome her with a song
column16: but then mistake her for a weed and order her to leave
column17: followed by a Caterpillar. He becomes enraged by her distress at her current height

column19: and turns into a butterfly. Before leaving

column21: and continues following the Rabbit. In the woods
column23: who advises her to visit the Mad Hatter or the March Hare to learn the Rabbit's location. She encounters both
column25: at the Hare's house having a mad tea party and celebrating their """unbirthdays""." They celebrate hers too
column26: but she becomes frustrated by interruptions whenever she tries to speak. As she prepares to leave
column28: continuing to exclaim that he is late; the Hatter examines his pocket watch and says it is """two" days "slow""
column29: and attempts to "fix""" it by filling it with food and tea but ends up having to destroy it after it goes """mad""." The Rabbit laments that his watch was an """unbirthday" "present""
column30: and the Hatter and Hare sing "The" Unbirthday "Song""" to him before throwing him back into the woods. Fed up with the nonsense
column32: but her surroundings have completely changed and she gets lost. Fearing she is lost forever
column33: she sits on a rock sobbing. The Cheshire Cat reappears and advises Alice to ask the Queen of Hearts for directions home
column34: showing her a """shortcut""" to the King and tyrannical Queen's castle. The Queen orders the beheading of a trio of playing card gardeners who mistakenly planted white roses instead of red ones (but paint them to make them look red)
column35: and forces Alice to play against her in a croquet match
column38: and hedgehogs are used as equipment. The equipment rig the game in favor of the Queen. The Cat appears again and plays a trick on the Queen
column39: causing her to fall over. The Cat disappears in time to make it look like Alice was the prankster
column40: but before the Queen can order her execution
